stories.text:
I recently learned how useful a db migration tool, AKA schema change management, can be. Most modern ORMs have this functionality. - https://sqlalchemy-migrate.readthedocs.io/en/latest/ - https://orkhan.gitbook.io/typeorm/docs/migrations - https://www.prisma.io/migrate

I've never seen data teams (building data warehouses or machine learning infra) use something similar. I was wondering if anyone had some theories as to why?
stories.title: Ask HN: Why don't engineers building data warehouses use a DB migration tool?
Ribs Is Already in the Kitchen: The Oven (2010)
Avoid exception throwing in performance-sensitive code

stories.text: When I got into this industry 10 years ago, the world was a completely different place. Bootcamps weren't a thing. Computer Science programs were still something just for the nerds. And the industry was almost entirely autodidacts like myself who grew up immersed in technology and did it for the joy of it. Fast forward, and now literally everyone and their uncle wants to be a software dev, and CS programs are churning out hundreds of thousands of graduates. The thought of competing against someone credentialled with 4-5 years experience vs. myself with 10 years and no credentials, seems hopeless. It almost seems like the path I took would be completely impossible today.
stories.title: Ask HN: Any other self taught devs terrified of interviewing these days?
Online Video Meme Editor – move text and images to create a motion effect
Examine v2 – Customer research: understanding why customers hire us
Coinbase Customers Sue over Stablecoin That’s ‘Anything But’

stories.text:
I've came across a number of news articles about the lack of privacy/security with the built-in car electronics systems lately. However, when I tried to find a solution, it seems like they either involve physically disconnecting some components (antenna, cellular chips) or buying a car from 10+ years ago without any of the newer features and with rather terrible fuel efficiency (compared to current ones, especially hybrids). Neither of these seem ideal, since disconnecting components isn't a foolproof way to ensure the data is no longer being collected, and it could theoretically be uploaded all at once when you take the car to a shop for warranty repair.

Is there a way to minimize data exposure when driving? I don't currently own a car, but I may want one at some point. Is there any hope left?

I'm not too worried about the data being collected by the government such as by speed cameras, even though it is certainly a problem too. I'm mainly focused on the data collected by the car or dealership companies, or 3rd party service providers, especially the location data.
stories.title: Ask HN: Driving a car without handing over all the data
